JAYS SWAMPED BY
ARMY BASKETEERS
Cadets Come Out On Long End
Of 36-17 Score
FIRST HALF ENDS IN TIE
Debuskey, Star Center, Fails
To Take Trip
The Black and Blue basketeers
tasted defeat again last Saturday
afternoon, this time at the hands
of the West Pointers to the tune of
36 to 17. The first half, in which
the Army second team opposed the
Jays, ended in an 8 to 8 tie. In the
second period, the Cadets played
their varsity, and swamped the visitors by a top-heavy score.
Defense Tight

The defense was tight on both
sides during the early periods of
the game, the first half ending with
the score standing at 8 all. Horst
drew first blood in the game by
sinking a free throw. Messinger
soon put the Army in the lead, however, by sinking one from the floor,
making the score 2 to 1. The Jays
had plenty of easy shots, but their
shooting was wild, and they missed
a number of chances to score. The
pace was hot all during the half,
with the Cadets leading, 8 to 4,
within a few minutes of the end.
Then Wood fouled Stude and the
Hopkins center made the try good,
bringing the total up to five points
for the Jays. Siegel, Pssarew and
Stude had each missed easy tries
immediately before this. Passarew
then failed on another trial, 'but
Horst made good on a try from the
side of the court, making it 8 to 7.
Passarew then tied the score by the
free-throw route, and the half
ended right afterward.
Second Period

The second period was a slaughter
for the Black and Blue. The Army
sent in its first team, and before the
half was a quarter gone had
amassed a total of 16 points, while
the Jays were idle on the firing line.
From then on, the radets were
never in danger, and the game ended
with the score standing at 36 to 17.
Stecker starred for the Army,
while Stude, Passarew and Siegel
all played well for the Black and
Blue.
Debuskey Absent

Price 5 Cents

ADAMS CONTEST TO
TAKE PLACE MARCH 6
Sophomores are urged to
enter the Adams Declamation
Contest which will take place
at the Assembly on March 6.
All entrants must signify their
intention of competing before
February 27, on which date a
preliminary elimination will be
held. Contestants should communicate at once with P. W.
Spear, President of the Debating Council, P. 0. 921.

You knock timidly on the door.
There is a gruff "Come in." You go
inside and attempt to proffer the
glad hand stuff. "My name, whoosis, glad to meetcha." Both of them
wilt you with a glance and tell you
to "sit down." You begin to feel
slightly nervous; there does not
seem to be any place to put your
hands. One of them asks questions
while the other gives you the "up
and down." Then they reverse
while the other talks. "Why do you
want to work for the Whichit Manufacturing Corporation." After you
think up the correct answer to this
so that the other man from the
American Gadget Company will not
be offended, the man calmly
scratches out the big "$150 a
month" you had placed on the application and gravely informs you
that they pay $108 a month. In
fact, we state it for an actual fact
that a prominent football man was
actually offered $21 a week by a
local concern.
Having read up an the company's
literature you try to appear intensely
interested in their ,product. In the
meantime they are making notes on
your appearance, neatness, personality, grit and what not. After
a short talk with each student the
men retire. A week later two men
receive bids, selected from the rest
by some method that will probably
remain forever hidden.
Perhaps the prize is taken by the
U. S. Civil Service Applications
which ask you "Do you drink ?"
and as a next question "If so, state
where and how much.

HALL ELECTED HEAD
OF LACROSSE TEAM
At a meeting of the members of the lacrosse team, Purnell Hall was elected captain.
The meeting was held Friday,
February 14, and was authorized by the A. A. Board. Hall
was a member of the lacrosse
team for the past three years.
Incidentally he is one of the
members of the Olympic lacrosse twelve.
T h e following members
were eligible to vote:
Nichols, Love, Campbell,
Dukehart, Guild, Hersberger,
Brownley, Kegan, Caplan,
Love, Lyons and Eagan.

Some weeks ago, in the columns of the American Magazine,
our Dean stated that the present
four-year college course is a waste
of time. The trouble is that our
Dean is correct—college is a squandering of precious years. Now, if
cur Dean were wrong, writing this
article would be an easy affair—
all I would have to do would be to
contradict our reference's arguments—but now, I've got to build
up a case for myself.
First of all, being a Dean isn't
quite the simple job we students
imagine it to be. An efficient Dean
must listen (seriously) to the
wail of an engineer who complains
that eight is too low a mark for the
best man in his class, to the sorrowful tales of trustees, to the longuishing suggestions of very unimportant instructors, and to the suave
advice of so-called campus leaders.
Besides all this, he must try to maintam n a .900 batting average in
guessing at fitting applicants for
medical school.
Maybe now, we have decided that
after all, perhaps our Dean actually
has had a chance to see every side
of our present college system. More
than anyone else, it is his task to
view every possible point in the disagreeable part of a collegiate system.
He has the opportunity of discovering why an age-old system is
archaic; and he states "colleges are
a waste of time."

wasted away. Its the same story

ANNOUNCES PROGRESS

GRADUATE CLUB WILL
HOLD TEA DANCES
The Graduate Club wishes
to announce that it will hold
two more tea-dances during
the present month of February. These dances will be held
in the Music Room of Levering Hall, on Wednesday, February 1,9, and Thursday, February 27, from 4.30 to 6.30.
The usual charge of $.25
will be charged the dancers
and will be collected as the
dancers leave. There will be
no night dance this month,
the next one will be held some
time during the latter portion
of March.

JAYS SWAMPED BY
ARMY BASKETEERS
Cadets Come Out On Long End
Of 36-17 Score
FIRST HALF ENDS IN TIE
Debuskey, Star Center, Fails
To Take Trip
The Black and Blue basketeers
tasted defeat again last Saturday
afternoon, this time at the hands
of the West Pointers to the tune of
36 to 17. The first half, in which
the Army second team opposed the
Jays, ended in an 8 to 8 tie. In the
second period, the Cadets played
their varsity, and swamped the visitors by a top-heavy score.
Defense Tight

The defense was tight on both
sides during the early periods of
the game, the first half ending with
the score standing at 8 all. Horst
drew first blood in the game by
sinking a free throw. Messinger
soon put the Army in the lead, however, by sinking one from the floor,
making the score 2 to 1. The Jays
had plenty of easy shots, but their
shooting was wild, and they missed
a number of chances to score. The
pace was hot all during the half,
with the Cadets leading, 8 to 4,
within a few minutes of the end.
Then Wood fouled Stude and the
Hopkins center made the try good,
bringing the total up to five points
for the Jays. Siegel, Pssarew and
Stude had each missed easy tries
immediately before this. Passarew
then failed on another trial, 'but
Horst made good on a try from the
side of the court, making it 8 to 7.
Passarew then tied the score by the
free-throw route, and the half
ended right afterward.
Second Period

The second period was a slaughter
for the Black and Blue. The Army
sent in its first team, and before the
half was a quarter gone had
amassed a total of 16 points, while
the Jays were idle on the firing line.
From then on, the radets were
never in danger, and the game ended
with the score standing at 36 to 17.
Stecker starred for the Army,
while Stude, Passarew and Siegel
all played well for the Black and
Blue.

You knock timidly on the door.
There is a gruff "Come in." You go
inside and attempt to proffer the
glad hand stuff. "My name, whoosis, glad to meetcha." Both of them
wilt you with a glance and tell you
to "sit down." You begin to feel
slightly nervous; there does not
seem to be any place to put your
hands. One of them asks questions
while the other gives you the "up
and down." Then they reverse
while the other talks. "Why do you
want to work for the Whichit Manufacturing Corporation." After you
think up the correct answer to this
so that the other man from the
American Gadget Company will not
be offended, the man calmly
scratches out the big "$150 a
month" you had placed on the application and gravely informs you
that they pay $108 a month. In
fact, we state it for an actual fact
that a prominent football man was
actually offered $21 a week by a
local concern.
Having read up an the company's
literature you try to appear intensely
interested in their ,product. In the
meantime they are making notes on
your appearance, neatness, personality, grit and what not. After
a short talk with each student the
men retire. A week later two men
receive bids, selected from the rest
by some method that will probably
remain forever hidden.
Perhaps the prize is taken by the
U. S. Civil Service Applications
which ask you "Do you drink ?"
and as a next question "If so, state
where and how much.

HALL ELECTED HEAD
OF LACROSSE TEAM
At a meeting of the members of the lacrosse team, Purnell Hall was elected captain.
The meeting was held Friday,
February 14, and was authorized by the A. A. Board. Hall
was a member of the lacrosse
team for the past three years.
Incidentally he is one of the
members of the Olympic lacrosse twelve.
T h e following members
were eligible to vote:
Nichols, Love, Campbell,
Dukehart, Guild, Hersberger,
Brownley, Kegan, Caplan,
Love, Lyons and Eagan.

Some weeks ago, in the columns of the American Magazine,
our Dean stated that the present
four-year college course is a waste
of time. The trouble is that our
Dean is correct—college is a squandering of precious years. Now, if
cur Dean were wrong, writing this
article would be an easy affair—
all I would have to do would be to
contradict our reference's arguments—but now, I've got to build
up a case for myself.
First of all, being a Dean isn't
quite the simple job we students
imagine it to be. An efficient Dean
must listen (seriously) to the
wail of an engineer who complains
that eight is too low a mark for the
best man in his class, to the sorrowful tales of trustees, to the longuishing suggestions of very unimportant instructors, and to the suave
advice of so-called campus leaders.
Besides all this, he must try to maintam n a .900 batting average in
guessing at fitting applicants for
medical school.
Maybe now, we have decided that
after all, perhaps our Dean actually
has had a chance to see every side
of our present college system. More
than anyone else, it is his task to
view every possible point in the disagreeable part of a collegiate system.
He has the opportunity of discovering why an age-old system is
archaic; and he states "colleges are
a waste of time."

maid from Eastern or Western
wastes half an hour explaining

able to keep the class together for

translation is started, and we think

aged linguist to tea on Sunday).

nouns, and negative antonyms for
each of his verbs. And so two more
hours of perfect monotony are
wasted away. Its the same story

HULLABALOO STAFF
ANNOUNCES PROGRESS

GRADUATE CLUB WILL
HOLD TEA DANCES
The Graduate Club wishes
to announce that it will hold
two more tea-dances during
the present month of February. These dances will be held
in the Music Room of Levering Hall, on Wednesday, February 1,9, and Thursday, February 27, from 4.30 to 6.30.
The usual charge of $.25
will be charged the dancers
and will be collected as the
dancers leave. There will be
no night dance this month,
the next one will be held some
time during the latter portion
of March.

COOPERATION IS URGED

write-ups be handed in by that time.

This year's sophomore class today
will attempt to continue its success
against the opposing class in a
swimming meet to be held at the
K. of C. pool at 4.30 P. M.
The freshman squad, however,
;s looking for a victory due to its
superiority of trained members, the
yearlings having turned out for
swimming in a greater majoritythan
their opponents. Both teams are
looking for new material as all the
positions are not as yet filled. The
frosh are especially on the lookout
for divers; whereas, the sophs can
use several men in a variety of
events.
According to a report issued by
the swimming managers, the blacklist in no way affects the competitors in inter-class events. Coach
Hambleton is training men appearing for berths.
